issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw:
Makes sense to me. We will probably need to fix our release script and procedures. How would gazebo 3.0 be released in older platforms like precise?

@nkoenig, @hsu : what do you think?

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw: The nightly builds should provide 3.0 functionality, so I don't think we necessarily need to package it for older platforms.
content.html: The nightly builds should provide 3.0 functionality, so I don't think we necessarily need to package it for older platforms.

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw: Gazebo 3.0 is not ready yet. There are a number of pending pull requests, and a few more that are blocked. What is the time frame?
content.html: Gazebo 3.0 is not ready yet. There are a number of pending pull requests, and a few more that are blocked. What is the time frame?

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw:
I'd suggest that for each Ubuntu Distro you plan to support 2 versions of Gazebo. One which is the stable one and one which is the new release. Note that this will grow to supporting potentially 4-5 versions simultaneously depending on how often you release due to the LTS cycles.  

We talked about this a bunch in the context of ROS: http://wiki.ros.org/Distributions/Timeline  If you expect a major version each year this will be a very close analogy.  

The choice on naming for each distro is subjective.  You could simply do gazebo and gazebo-current for each one representing N and N+1 where N is the latest stable release if you do not expect to support side by side installations. If there's a major API change gazeboX should be considered to force packagers to update their dependencies(and hopefully fix the broken code).
content.html:
I'd suggest that for each Ubuntu Distro you plan to support 2 versions of Gazebo. One which is the stable one and one which is the new release. Note that this will grow to supporting potentially 4-5 versions simultaneously depending on how often you release due to the LTS cycles.

We talked about this a bunch in the context of ROS: http://wiki.ros.org/Distributions/Timeline If you expect a major version each year this will be a very close analogy.

The choice on naming for each distro is subjective. You could simply do gazebo and gazebo-current for each one representing N and N+1 where N is the latest stable release if you do not expect to support side by side installations. If there's a major API change gazeboX should be considered to force packagers to update their dependencies(and hopefully fix the broken code).

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw: @tfoote after speak with the rest of the team, we can start producing gazebo (2.X series) for Saucy, not a problem. What is the time frame for the inclusion in Indigo? When would you need it?
content.html: @tfoote after speak with the rest of the team, we can start producing gazebo (2.X series) for Saucy, not a problem. What is the time frame for the inclusion in Indigo? When would you need it?

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw: We're working hard to spin things up for indigo to get testing on trusty early.  Early next week would be great. We can keep the older one for a little while, but the sooner the better.
content.html: We're working hard to spin things up for indigo to get testing on trusty early. Early next week would be great. We can keep the older one for a little while, but the sooner the better.

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.raw: This is a bit dated now. Is it too late to get gazebo 2.2 into saucy? Also, what should the gazebo 2.2 package be named (`gazebo` or `gazebo2`)? I can't remember if these things were decided or not.
content.html: This is a bit dated now. Is it too late to get gazebo 2.2 into saucy? Also, what should the gazebo 2.2 package be named (gazebo or gazebo2)? I can't remember if these things were decided or not.

issue.title: Release gazebo 2.1.0 as gazebo on saucy

content.html:
We decided to go with gazebo2 name for the package. The beta version was sent to ROS ninjas in this form.

AFAIK, as far as we respect the ABI, we can request an update of our gazebo2 package at any time in any working ROS distribution.

@tfoote feel free to suggest me the best moment to update with our latest 2.X release.
